Reports Primary Energy - the amount of energy required at source,before conversion and transmission, to meet the calculatedenergy demand of the dwelling (Units: kWh/m2/year).
The total floor area of the dwelling. This excludes any unheatedancillary buildings. (Units: m2)
Calculation illustrating the total energy cost for heating, cooling,lighting, and ventilating the building. Based on standardisedoccupancy patterns and fuel costs. (Units: Â£)
Calculation illustrating the energy cost saving that may beachieved if the listed improvement measures are carried out.Based on standardised occupancy patterns and fuel costs. (Units:Â£)
Current Energy Efficiency Rating expressed on a Scale of G to A, with A being the highest (best) rating band
Current energy cost rating (EER or â€˜SAP ratingâ€™) for the buildingwhich is calculated using both the energy efficiency of the buildingand the cost of fuels used.

Potential energy cost rating for the building, after application ofthe listed improvement measures, which is again calculated usingboth the energy efficiency of the improved building and the costof fuels used.
Potential Energy Efficiency Rating expressed on a Scale of G to A,with A being the highest (best) rating band.
Current environmental impact for the building which is calculatedusing the emissions associated with the energy use of thebuilding.
Current Environmental Impact Rating expressed on a Scale of G toA, with A being the highest (best) rating band.
Potential environmental impact for the building, after applicationof the listed improvement measures, which is again calculatedusing the emissions associated with the energy use of thebuilding.
Potential Environmental Impact Rating expressed on a Scale of Gto A, with A being the highest (best) rating band.
Annual CO2 equivalent emissions per square metre of floor area(units: kg.CO2e/m2/yr)

Summary of the performance of this building element, reported inthe following format: â€˜Description; Energy Efficiency Rating;Environmental Efficiency Rating.â€™  Both ratings elements arereported on a scale of 1 to 5 (very poor, poor, average, good, verygood). Note: where a dwelling has more than one type of thiselement, multiple elements can be reported. Each elementreported is separated by â€œ|â€ [ASCII (decimal) 124]

The mean of fuel_poverty_score_oa over all output areas in a local authority. Header changed from "combined_fuel_poverty_score_v3" to "fuel_poverty_score".
The mean of fuel_poverty_score_oa over all output areas in an LSOA. Header changed from "combined_fuel_poverty_score_v3" to "fuel_poverty_score".

A score from 0-100 predicting the relative potential benefit of home improvements in reducing fuel poverty in each census output area. The output areas likely to benefit the most (of all the areas where the score is calculated) will have a score of 100. The output areas with the least potential impact on fuel poverty will have a score of 0. The score is calculated as the min-max normalised mean value of the following features after they are standardised: percentage_uc_population_oa; energy_efficiency_c_gap_mean_oa; percentage_devices_fuel_poor_gas_smoothed_lsoa; percentage_devices_fuel_poor_electricity_smoothed_lsoa. UPDATE: percentage_uc_population_oa now uses num_uprns_oa instead of working-age population estimates. Header changed from "combined_fuel_poverty_score_v3" to "fuel_poverty_score".

The standard error of fuel_poverty_score_oa over all output areas in an LSOA. Header changed from "combined_fuel_poverty_score_v3" to "fuel_poverty_score".
